data.title: Replace the default find/replace package in Atom
data.body:
This replaces the [Command Panel](https://github.com/atom/command-panel) with [Find and Replace](https://github.com/atom/find-and-replace). Find and Replace now has same functionality as the Command Panel, so I think now is a good time to switch it to be the default.

The Command Panel has the potential to be very powerful, but it has a syntax most people are unaware of. The reason for moving to the Find and Replace package is to give people a more familiar interface.

![atom - _users_corey_github_atom](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/596/1160349/6db52810-1fd7-11e3-949c-eab3ad1a4fe3.jpg)

![atom - _users_corey_github_atom-1](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/596/1160355/8bfe7772-1fd7-11e3-8aa3-353da8fd504f.jpg)

data.title: Private Alpha Focus List
data.body:
It's a rolling set of tactical items that we can work on. It's meant more of as a todo list than a comment thread.
## Blockers to Dec 4th
- [x] Pick the first 5 private alpha users
  - @shama 
  - @maxbrunsfeld
  - @garand 
  - @maxogden
  - @caseycrites
- [x] Write the invitation email (Include download link, campfire username/email request and "don't tell anyone about this" language)
- [ ] Land new telepath and refactor panes @nathansobo 
- [x] A user understands what to do on the first run and can give feedback #903 @probablycorey 
- [x] A user can learn about atom, download it and discover packages on atom.io @thedaniel 
- [ ] Atom has a fully documented Public API
- [x] Pick a license and add a `LICENSE.md` to atom/atom and all package repos #1155 
## Dec 11th
- [ ] Make sure `whitespace`, `bracket-matcher`, `image-view`, `archive-view` and `find-and-replace` conform to best practices.
## Icebox
- [ ] Left and right panels
- [ ] A user can edit keybindings #628 
- [ ] Collaboration
- [ ] A user can add multiple projects to a workspace #770 
- [ ] Aliases commands in palette so people can find tree-view by typing folder
## Completed
- [x] Cleanse atom/atom for public consumption. @kevinsawicki
- [x] `rootView` -> `workspaceView` @kevinsawicki
- [x] Allow non-boxen users to `script/bootstrap` @probablycorey
- [x] Security review (keytar, rm -fr, github-sign-in) @probablycorey
- [x] Atom doesn't crash when opening large files @probablycorey
- [x] Project find (see #885) @benogle 
- [x] Project replace (see atom/find-and-replace@8e5c9a8) @probablycorey
- [x] Find and replace (see #855) @probablycorey
- [x] A user can right click and add a file using the tree view (see #850) @mcolyer
- [x] Atom reports metrics (see atom/metrics#1) @mcolyer
- [x] Public api exported via `require 'atom'` see #853 @kevinsawicki
- [x] `apm init --package` @mcolyer
- [x] A user can generate a theme (like the package generator) @mcolyer
- [x] A user can correct a mis-spelling by right clicking (see #840) @mcolyer
- [x] Collaboration works (see #794, #793, #792) @kevinsawicki
- [x] Atom informs users about slow packages #868 @kevinsawicki 
- [x] Exception reporting with backtraces (see #869) @mcolyer
- [x] A user can find and install a theme using settings-view (see atom/settings-view#8) @mcolyer
- [x] Two factor sign-in works (see atom/github-sign-in#1) @kevinsawicki
- [x] Atom launch speed #621 @kevinsawicki 
- [x] Clean up globals #881 @kevinsawicki
- [x] Match Sublime's multiple selection functionality #523 @kevinsawicki 
- [x] Packages can add items to the global menu. @mcolyer
- [x] Document the documentation @mcolyer
- [x] Atom needs developer guides @mcolyer
- [x] Apm switch to releases atom/apm#23 @kevinsawicki 
- [x] Windows support @paulcbetts @mcolyer
- [x] Add folder / file
- [x] Support move operations in telepath @nathansobo
- [x] Make command keys match sublime #1025 @probablycorey 
- [x] Atom is fast and relatively GC-pause-free @nathansobo 
- [x] Single user mode for telepath (so it can open large files #307) @nathansobo @kevinsawicki
- [x] Windows specs passing @mcolyer 
- [x] Global status bar always visible @benogle 
- [x] Refactors @kevinsawicki

data.title: Public API
data.body:
This is a pull request to get the public Atom API going.

Basically it adds an `exports` folder on the `NODE_PATH` that can be used by packages to require things from core.

`src` will eventually be removed from the `NODE_PATH` so every internal class will no longer be visible to packages.

Packages would do things like `{$, RootView} = require 'atom-api'` to access classes from the public API. 

`atom-api` will be renamed to `atom` once it doesn't clash with the existing `atom.coffee` in `src/`.
- [x] Add `exports/` to `NODE_PATH`
- [x] Update core specs to use relative require paths
- [x] Update core classes to use relative require paths
- [x] Remove `src/` from `NODE_PATH`
- [x] Remove `vendor/` from `NODE_PATH`
- [x] Remove `static/` from `NODE_PATH`
- [x] Remove `spec/` from `NODE_PATH`
- [x] Remove resource path from `NODE_PATH`
- [x] Rename `atom-api` to `atom`
- [x] Convert all packages to `require 'atom'`
- [x] Doc all classes/methods in the public API
# What's in the public API?
- [BufferedNodeProcess](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/buffered-node-process.coffee)
- [BufferedProcess](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/buffered-process.coffee)
- [Editor](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/editor.coffee) :triangular_flag_on_post:
- [Directory](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/directory.coffee)
- [EventEmitter](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/event-emitter.coffee)
- [File](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/file.coffee)
- [Git](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/git.coffee)
- [fs](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/fs-utils.coffee)
- [RootView](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/root-view.coffee) :triangular_flag_on_post:
- [ScrollView](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/scroll-view.coffee)
- [SelectList](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/select-list.coffee) :triangular_flag_on_post:
- [Subscriber](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/subscriber.coffee)
- [Task](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/task.coffee) :triangular_flag_on_post:
- [pathForRepositoryUrl()](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/project.coffee)  :triangular_flag_on_post:
- `$` as jquery with our extensions
- `_` as underscore with our extensions
- `$$`, `$$$`, and `View` from SpacePen with our extensions
- `Point` and `Range` from telepath
- `stringscore` from vendor

:triangular_flag_on_post: Not exported when running as node child process

data.title: Improve IME support
data.body:
- Make IME's input bubble follow the cursor.
- Fix OS X's accented character suggestion. (https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/50)
- Show IME's composition text in the editor (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/795)

data.title: Context menu
data.body:
A discussion with code.

So we'd like to have context menus which populate with menu items based on the DOM element that was right clicked. This branch is a working proposal that does that (there's a corresponding tree-view branch).

I'm thinking that it should follow the pattern we've put forth with keybindings, use a css selector to specify the relevant elements and then list the label and it's corresponding command to trigger. I'd be open to adding this as a dedicated file in the atom package format like keymaps but I feel like it might be nicer to register another export function in packages (something like `registerContextMenus`). Or maybe packages should call onto globals like is done currently. Thoughts?
## TODO
- [ ] Clean up the inspect element stuff and register it in the proper place
- [ ] Write tests once, after agreement on approach.

data.title: Project scan additions
data.body:
- Use the -G option in nak (depends on gjtorikian/nak#29)
- Add more info to the output

data.title: Cache LESS files
data.body:
- [x] Use [less-cache](https://github.com/atom/less-cache) to cache compiled LESS files to `/tmp/atom-compile-cache/less`.
- [x] Bundle pre-built caches for light/dark ui/syntax combinations

This makes opening a dev window go from 3 seconds to 1 second on my machine.

data.title: Ask for comment character when toggling line comments when unknown
data.body: If I'm editing a file (in this case play/play's `mpd.conf`) and there isn't a known comment syntax for the file, when I toggle line comments, Atom should ask me what the comment character is. You know, like `comment-region` in Emacs.

data.title: $::flashError() doesn't work anymore
data.body:
It current [adds the class .error](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/jquery-extensions.coffee#L76-L79) but after the new styling changes that class does nothing.

I tried to use `highlight-error` but it has a very low selector score and loses. Should we have a high scoring error selector we can use? 

/cc @benogle

data.title: Can't create two unsaved buffers (tabs)
data.body:
Livin' this temp lifestyle and getting no love from command-N

To reproduce:
- Open atom, create a new file, get some good old fashioned words in there and save iiittt
- command-N gets you a new tab
- gimme some words in there, but don't save it yet. live on the edge
- :zap: got a crazy new idea, gimme another new tab (command-N) so I can get my thoughts down
- nooooooooooooo love

I would :heart: to be able to have any number of unsaved tabs open, cause I live dangerously like that

data.title: Add custom resource loader, fixes #197
data.body:
See #197 for the original issue.

This PR adds protocol handler for the `atom` protocol, so network (or file) requests with URLs of `atom` protocol would respect the load path similar to `require` and `requireStylesheet`. For example, `atom://archive-view/images/zip.png` would be resolved to `~/.atom/packages/archive-view/images/zip.png` or `/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/node_modules/archive-view/images/zip.png`.

But also note that we have to explicitly specify package's name in the URL, since it's very difficult to find out from which file the request was sent. More discussions can be found at https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/pull/65.

data.title: Only attach the mousewheel handler on regular editors. Fix #838
data.body: Mini editor capture the mousewheel events. This fixes it. See #838

data.title: Reverse the loading order of themes
data.body:
Right now theme loading order is a bit non-intuitive. Visually in the settings, themes are stacked vertically. My expectation is that the top most theme should override any styles defined in themes below.

This is currently true for the `ui-variables` loading -- the top-most theme's `ui-variables` are picked to override any other `ui-variables` files.

But theme loading is currently the opposite -- themes are loaded top to bottom, so the bottom theme can override things on the top theme.

This pull reverses the order of theme loading so the top-most theme is loaded last. That way, the top-most theme's styles can override any styles defined by themes below/after it.

data.title: Fix .block css definition. Fixes #836
data.body: It was selecting .blocks in the highlighted syntax. See #836

data.title: Native Spell Check
data.body:
Noticed that even though you can see a word is incorrectly spelled you are unable to change it. I think I'd rather 'inspect element' had a key modifier attached to it since the spell checker is normal to the OS. I understand in the browser is 'normal' but it makes sense to me to have right click correct the word. Thoughts? 

![animated-2013-09-12_16h-12m-26s](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/51578/1133946/b6981ae0-1be7-11e3-8002-65d9b4452058.gif)

data.title: Style the settings panel
data.body:
It looked terrible with the addition of the new theme. This adds components in the themes to make the settings look reasonable. 

Depends on #810.

data.title: Mini editors capture the scroll wheel
data.body: On the settings general panel, scroll through the settings. When your mouse is over the mini editors, it will not scroll the page. IMO, mini editors should not capture the scroll events.

data.title: Open file at specific line
data.body:
So this was inspired by #704. I'm open to feedback here as to how this should be done, this was my best guess as to how to properly implement this.

The proposed syntax is as follows, `atom file.coffee:12` would open the file.coffee at line 12. @paulcbetts is it a bad idea to use a colon as a the separator here (not sure about what's valid in windows)?

data.title: Ruby mode gets confused with procs/commas
data.body:
If you open Gist's user.rb in Atom (2304518a1e7c42d6311706118b20d1020d28b222) you see this for [line 29](https://github.com/github/gist/blob/06de8e30777f5ba5a2d71a71dafed79877aa639a/app/models/user.rb#L29):

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/1126208/45615e8a-1b20-11e3-8f94-51901ae7fb22.png)

Looks weird. Switching to Plain Text mode fixes it:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/1126207/4018a3ac-1b20-11e3-8006-db6284834dbe.png)

Seems like it's happening for any blocks which means I can't write Ruby in Atom right now as all the lines after the proc get confused.

data.title: Fixes for theme live-reloading
data.body:
There were a number of additions I needed to get https://github.com/atom/dev-live-reload to work. I tried to minimize my changes. The theme API could be better, but I think this is the first package that accesses it.

This could conceivably be split into a couple of pull requests:
- theme API updates
- stylesheet reloading updates
- fix to file.coffee

data.title: Keybinding lookup a la Emacs `describe-key` function
data.body: It is sometimes interesting and useful to see what function a keybinding is assigned to in the current context - i have used this to debug my emacs configuration in the past and would love to have it in Atom. Basically, you invoke `describe-key` and then smash some keys, and the editor tells you what function that keybinding would have run.

data.title: Project search speed and core.excludeVcsIgnoredPaths
data.body:
After talking with @probablycorey and @benogle today they mentioned that `Project.scan` had been reported in the past as slow on larger repos (ie github/github). So I spent some time investigating what was happening.

I ended up using mirror/chromium as my test repository. It has roughly ~51,000 files whereas github/github has ~13,000 files. So when I benchmarked `nak`, `ag`, and `ack` I found that `nak` fell solidly between the two of them. `nak` took about ~25s, `ag` took ~15s and `ack` ~40s.

I also investigated the overhead of shelling out to another process (as that's how we use `nak` to avoid issues with node's eventloop within Chrome). It turned out that this was minimal and definitely worth it to avoid blocking the UI.

When running `nak` against github/github within atom we found that the first result would be returned within ~1.7s and the last around ~5s. After taking a closer look at `nak`'s algorithm it's difficult to reduce the time of the first result as it depends on searching all results for sorting before returning. If we didn't sort it could cause the UI to stutter as things may be inserted at the top of the list (which is undesirable).

After further investigation, @probablycorey and I found that the `core.excludeVcsIgnoredPaths` option had a significant impact on github/github searching (without it searching would take ~10s) but it's disabled by default. 

So long story short I'm purposing that we default `core.excludeVcsIgnoredPaths` to true as I believe users would expect it and everyone would enjoy the faster searching.

data.title: Publish docs don't need patch versions
data.body:
I don't think documentation urls should have patch versions in them (ie I think it should be `/v26.0/` and _not_ `/v26.0.0/`).

I'll leave this open for a day and see if anyone disagrees, if not I'll merge it.

data.title: Bump biscotto version
data.body: Fixes #551.

data.title: Bring back old coffee cache strategy
data.body:
The coffee-cache module is no longer working for us since when you sync back to an older version of a module the cache thinks the file is older than the cached version and therefore doesn't recompile it.

This PR brings back our old pre-node strategy of using the digest of a file's content to determine its cache path.

data.title: How do semantic commands get defined?
data.body:
_Note: I've created a new tag, 'noob-docs', to file bugs that I had trouble with as someone who doesn't know what they're doing, so that we can make the experience of writing plugins more rad._

While trying to create a plugin, it made sense how keymaps mapped to semantic events. However, neither the package generator nor the docs made it very clear how semantic commands are defined or how they are called. They're clearly a method, but attached to what class? How can I give my command a friendly name? Unclear.

data.title: Add metrics package to default bundle
data.body:
This allows us to collect some basic metrics about our users. See atom/metrics for more details.

I think we should install this be default so that's why I've included in the bundled packages. If we're cool with this I'll merge.

data.title: Word boundaries when double clicking words
data.body:
I like to double click words to highlight them.  I find if I'm too close to some punctuation (a period or parentheses, for instance), the highlight grabs that character too.  

![notification center](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/21/1092505/70201976-1680-11e3-8967-e7c76ac54932.png)

data.title: Make benchmarks runnable via command
data.body: We lost benchmark running in the atom-shell purge, this brings them back.
